title: Dwelling of the Immortals
text:
Born in Nanking, Kung Hsien studied painting with Tung Ch'i-chang (1555-1636) and literature with the Buddhist monk Chueh-lang Tao-sheng (1552-1659). Kung maintained loyalty to the fallen Ming dynasty under which he had been born and educated. When Manchus arrested his tutor Chueh-lang in 1647, Kung fled to Hai-an and did not return to Nanking until 1664. Deeply concerned with artistic legacy and aesthetic concepts, he developed a strongly personal style of form and images created with dark, heavily textured strokes and dots comprising graphically striking abstractions of light and dark.

The inscription reads:

Cloudy mountains soar indistinctly

to the border where heaven begins;

A solitary storied building below,

truly holds the eye.

I once asked where immortals' dwellings were located;

Old ears (Lao tzu) wrote in his book,

in the wine jar of the late Emperor

Kung Hsien of Lu-ch'eng ("City of Deer")

The reference to the "city of deer" is a metaphor for the imperial throne which, during much of Ming, had been located in Nanking.
